newsitem.title: USA: Senators struggle over Iraq resolution.
newsitem.headline: Senators struggle over Iraq resolution.

text.p: Key senators struggled on Wednesday to draft a bipartisan resolution supporting the U.S. military action against Iraq, but Republicans and Democrats differed on how much credit to give to President Bill Clinton.

As administration officials briefed senators on the two cruise missile strikes against targets in southern Iraq, Republicans also raised questions about future U.S. policy towards the Saddam Hussein government.
Negotiations on a support-the-troops resolution that had been expected to go before the Senate on Wednesday were being led by Republican Leader Trent Lott and Democratic Leader Tom Daschle.

Democrat John Kerry of Massachusetts, speaking to reporters following the briefing by Defence and State Department officials, said the problem was "about how much credit one party is willing to give another and exactly how comprehensive people are willing to be."
He said he hoped Republicans would join in sending a strong message of support for the country, U.S. military personnel and the president's actions.
But Texas Republican Kay Bailey Hutchison said: "I think the consensus is that we need more information before poeople decide what to say in a resolution."
She called for clarification of U.S. goals before there were any further military steps.
"It is very important that we have clear objectives... and that Congress understands what the ramifications are and what will be the end game," Hutchison said.
The U.S. military action has won support in Congress but some Republicans have faulted Clinton's earlier policy towards Iraq.
